items.title: What happened with commit 9b843d4?
items.body:
When I look at recent commits on the master branch, I see up through 801c740 ("Merge pull request #24 from jeffreydwalter/master").  However, when browsing by tag, I can see the next commit after that, 9b843d4 ("1.4"). 

We keep a mirror of this repo at gsutil-mirrors/monotonic, and when syncing with your repository, I had to `git checkout 1.4`, then push using the specific commit hash to get our mirror to pick up the latest commit; i.e., `git push --tags github-gsutil-mirror master` would not work, but `git push --tags github-gsutil-mirror 9b843d4:master` did.

items.title: find_library() does not find librt.so on Synology ppc linux in python 2.x
items.body:
Hello,

I am trying to use monotonic in a python2 script on my Synology NAS:
`Linux 2.6.32.12 #15152 SMP Fri Jul 14 13:18:16 CST 2017 ppc GNU/Linux synology_qoriq_413`

When I try to use the library with python2.x, I get the following exception: 
```
root@Synology:/# python2 blah.py 
  File "blah.py", line 162, in <module>
    raise RuntimeError('no suitable implementation for this system')
RuntimeError: ('no suitable implementation for this system')
```
When I run the same script on python3, I get the time:
```
root@Synology:/# python3 blah.py 
1062015.374837333
```

I put some debugging into your source and found out that there are two issues.
1. The main issue is that load_library() isn't finding 'rt'.
2. The other issue is that you have nested try/except blocks, and the try/except block around the calls to load_library() is catching `AttributeError`, but in python2.x load_library() is throwing a RuntimeException, so it's only attempting to load 'c' and when that fails the library raises the `  raise RuntimeError('no suitable implementation for this system')` exception.

If I change the code for *nix to this:
```
123             try:
124                 clock_gettime = ctypes.CDLL(ctypes.util.find_library('c'), use_errno=True).clock_gettime
125             except Exception as ex:
126                 try:
127                     clock_gettime = ctypes.CDLL(ctypes.util.find_library('rt'), use_errno=True).clock_gettime
128                 except Exception as ex:
129                     clock_gettime = ctypes.CDLL("librt.so.1", use_errno=True).clock_gettime
```

It works in both python2.x and python 3.

items.title: Support FreeBSD (currently - RuntimeError no suitable implementation)
items.body:
Relevant code in similar library: https://github.com/gavinbeatty/python-monotonic-time/blob/master/monotonic_time.py.in#L59

Boils down to:
* Linux `clock_gettime(1, &ts)`
* FreeBSD `clock_gettime(4, &ts)`

where 4 is also `#define CLOCK_MONOTONIC	4` in https://github.com/freebsd/freebsd/blob/master/include/time.h

Please, add support for FreeBSD.

items.title: conda-forge maintainers
items.body: Hi @atdt, I am developing a Python package ([Zarr](http://zarr.readthedocs.io/en/latest/)) which depends on monotonic via fasteners. I recently added Zarr to [conda-forge](http://conda-forge.github.io) to simplify installation for people using conda, and as part of making that possible I also needed to add monotonic to conda-forge. I've created a [feedstock for the monotonic package](https://github.com/conda-forge/monotonic-feedstock) and would be very happy to add you as a maintainer, which would mean that you could keep the recipe up to date with any new monotonic releases. Just let me know if you'd like me to add you as a maintainer, and/or anyone else. Thanks again.

items.title: PyPI classifiers not working, upload universal wheel
items.body:
I noticed that for some reason this package shows up as "Not Python 3 ready" on http://py3readiness.org/ Looking at this on PyPI, there are no classifiers listed on the entry.

Also, if you're mucking around with PyPI, could you upload a [universal wheel](https://python-packaging-user-guide.readthedocs.org/en/latest/distributing/#universal-wheels) (rather than just for Py2?).

items.title: OS X 10.11: RunTimeError('no suitable implementation for this system')
items.body:
Hi there,

Not sure if I should ask this here, but running the following command results in a 'no suitable implementation for this system' RunTimeError.

`
$ nova -h
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/bin/nova", line 9, in <module>
    load_entry_point('python-novaclient==2.31.0', 'console_scripts', 'nova')()
  File "/System/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/Extras/lib/python/pkg_resources.py", line 357, in load_entry_point
    return get_distribution(dist).load_entry_point(group, name)
  File "/System/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/Extras/lib/python/pkg_resources.py", line 2394, in load_entry_point
    return ep.load()
  File "/System/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/Extras/lib/python/pkg_resources.py", line 2108, in load
    entry = __import__(self.module_name, globals(),globals(), ['__name__'])
  File "/Library/Python/2.7/site-packages/python_novaclient-2.31.0-py2.7.egg/novaclient/__init__.py", line 17, in <module>
    from novaclient import api_versions
  File "/Library/Python/2.7/site-packages/python_novaclient-2.31.0-py2.7.egg/novaclient/api_versions.py", line 26, in <module>
    from novaclient import utils
  File "/Library/Python/2.7/site-packages/python_novaclient-2.31.0-py2.7.egg/novaclient/utils.py", line 21, in <module>
    from oslo_serialization import jsonutils
  File "/Library/Python/2.7/site-packages/oslo_serialization/jsonutils.py", line 60, in <module>
    from oslo_utils import timeutils
  File "/Library/Python/2.7/site-packages/oslo_utils/timeutils.py", line 26, in <module>
    from monotonic import monotonic as now  # noqa
  File "build/bdist.macosx-10.11-intel/egg/monotonic.py", line 148, in <module>
    raise RuntimeError('no suitable implementation for this system')
RuntimeError: no suitable implementation for this system
`

Am I missing something monotonic needs, or is this a python-novaclient issue?

I'm Running on OS X 10.11 El Capitan with Python 2.7.10.

Regards,
Lennart

items.title: Set CLOCK_MONOTONIC is not set for Cygwin
items.body:
Running the latest ansible on cygwin I ran into this issue.

An exception occurred during task execution. The full traceback is:
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/evega/.ansible/tmp/ansible-tmp-1437655132.65-127813728274004/os_se                                                                                                                      rver", line 24, in <module>
    import shade
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/shade/**init**.py", line 22, in <module                                                                                                                      >
    from cinderclient.v1 import client as cinder_client
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/cinderclient/v1/**init**.py", line 17,                                                                                                                       in <module>
    from cinderclient.v1.client import Client     # noqa
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/cinderclient/v1/client.py", line 16, in                                                                                                                       <module>
    from cinderclient import client
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/cinderclient/client.py", line 25, in <m                                                                                                                      odule>
    from keystoneclient import access
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/keystoneclient/access.py", line 20, in                                                                                                                       <module>
    from oslo_utils import timeutils
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/oslo_utils/timeutils.py", line 26, in <                                                                                                                      module>
    from monotonic import monotonic as now  # noqa
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/monotonic.py", line 136, in <module>
    raise RuntimeError('no suitable implementation for this system')
RuntimeError: no suitable implementation for this system

I believe the fix would be to change the if statement to 
            if sys.platform.startswith('linux'):
                if compare_versions(get_os_release(), '2.6.28') > 0:
                    CLOCK_MONOTONIC = 4  # CLOCK_MONOTONIC_RAW
                else:
                    CLOCK_MONOTONIC = 1
            elif sys.platform.startswith('freebsd'):
                CLOCK_MONOTONIC = 4
            elif sys.platform.startswith('cygwin'):
                CLOCK_MONOTONIC = 4
            elif 'bsd' in sys.platform:
                CLOCK_MONOTONIC = 3

Hi!

It seems like there is no Git tag for the 0.1 release found on PyPI. is that intended?

Best, Sebastian

items.title: monotonic fails on Windows
items.body:
The issue is here:

https://github.com/atdt/monotonic/blob/1ff1ba9f75f7251235ca66bebf92debe18cc898e/monotonic.py#L116-L117

On Windows, monotonic() - monotonic() returns 0.0, so replacing the >= check with > solves the issue

items.title: Using CLOCK_MONOTONIC rather than _RAW in Linux?
items.body:
Hi!

I noticed that the current code uses CLOCK_MONOTONIC (value 1) rather than CLOCK_MONOTONIC_RAW (value 4) on Linux
(https://github.com/atdt/monotonic/blob/master/monotonic.py#L101)
and is therefore

> affected by the incremental adjustments performed by adjtime(3) and NTP.

according to `man clock_gettime` on Debian wheezy.

The situation in `/usr/include` is this:

```
$ fgrep -R "define CLOCK_MONOTONIC" /usr/include/ | fgrep -v COARSE
/usr/include/linux/time.h:#define CLOCK_MONOTONIC           1
/usr/include/linux/time.h:#define CLOCK_MONOTONIC_RAW       4
/usr/include/bits/time.h:#   define CLOCK_MONOTONIC     1
/usr/include/bits/time.h:#   define CLOCK_MONOTONIC_RAW     4
/usr/include/x86_64-linux-gnu/bits/time.h:#   define CLOCK_MONOTONIC        1
/usr/include/x86_64-linux-gnu/bits/time.h:#   define CLOCK_MONOTONIC_RAW        4
```

Is this a bug or a feature?

At least in my case of measuring runtimes (and timouts) my current impression is that I would rather use CLOCK_MONOTONIC_RAW, i.e. be not affected by NTP.

What do you think?

Best, Sebastian
